Add UTM Parameters to a URL

A simple tool to help you track URL clicks in Google Analytics and other tools. Do you need a UTM parameter refresher? See the primer below.

How do UTM parameters work?

Consider this scenario: myproduct.com (the client) buys an ad package from citynews.com (the publisher). A link to myproduct.com will appear on the citynews.com website and in the citynews.com email newsletter.

The next day, a reader on the citynews.com website clicks on the ad and goes to myproduct.com. Later that day, another reader opens the citynews.com email newsletter and clicks on the email ad and goes to myproduct.com.

When the client goes into Google Analytics (or any other analytics tool), they will see that two people clicked on myproduct.com. But that's not very helpful! The client would like to know a lot more about where those ad clicks came from, so they can adjust their ad order with citynews.com next month.

This is the problem that UTM parameters help solve. The client, perhaps with help from the publisher, adds additonal information to their URL in the form of UTM parameters.

For ads that appear on the citynews.com website, the client uses the URL

https://myproduct.com/?utm_source=citynews&utm_medium=website

For ads that appear in the citynews.com email newsletter, the client uses the URL

https://myproduct.com/?utm_source=citynews&utm_medium=email

Now when the client goes into Google Analytics, they will be able to see the source of the clicks and the marketing medium used to deliver the clicks. So much more helpful!

But wait, there's more. The utm_campaign parameter may be used to indicate the marketing campaign or ad buy associated with the link, and the utm_content parameter may be used to indicate the link's location on the webpage or email. The form above makes it easy to add all of these parameters.

Why are UTM parameters so... difficult?

Although there are some reliable guidelines for how to use UTM parameters, there are no "right" answers or hard-and-fast rules. Why? Because the "right" answers are determined by what the client wants or expects to see in Google Analytics. For example, should utm_source be set to

  • citynews
  • citynews.com
  • City News
  • ...?

These questions need to be 1) answered by the client or 2) answered by the publisher and communicated to the client.
